Genuinely an absolute masterpiece. While it is billed as a roguelike (the classic definition, no meta progression and top down tile based dungeon crawler with permadeath) it can be played like a (really hard) rpg with respawn options for someone more focused on the world and the story. It's so damn creative with its mechanics from planting a nuke and phasing out of reality to avoid the blast, cybernetically wiring a massive floating throne to your spine and firing a massive phase canon from said throne, or wielding 13 axes with the horrible ball of limbs you have become. There is a steep learning curve and it can be hard to get some of the really good lore out from between the markov text but if you're willing to put in the work this is an absolute masterclass in game design. 

10/10, play the game.

185964315.review:
I recommend this with the caveat that you should get some tips from youtubers or the caves of qud wiki first, and watch a bit of gameplay footage to see if it is your cup of tea. The built in tutorial does teach some things, but it will be frustratingly difficult unless you get tips or think critically about your actions in the game. If you prefer to play blind, don't be afraid to switch to "roleplay" mode in character creation, or be okay with your character dying and starting over.

If you find yourself surrounded or unexpectedly chunked for a lot of HP, take your time between each move! Retreating to a staircase or a choke-point is optimal a lot of the time.

Also, the scale of each rogue LIKE run is quite large. You can easily spend upwards of 10 to 20 hours on a run, which is different from the rogue LITEs that are most popular nowadays.

One of the best parts of the game is the emergent gameplay, which many other reviews describe. The game took a very small team over a decade to develop! In particular, the dialogue and descriptive writing is a strong point.

Then saw a video of a guy who through a long series of spells and abilities was able to transfer his consciousness into a door.  Had 5000 HP but no arms to hold weapons.  Survived quite a while.

185937285.review:
Short review: I rolled up a psychic gunslinger with the ability to open holes in space and a random chance of spawning a doppelganger any time he enters a new map. Proceeded to get shot to death by my evil twin while wrestling with an irate baboon and being pelted with rocks. Three thumbs up! (The third sprouted out of my chest when I gained a level. It just lives here now.)

Longer review: If you've ever enjoyed the style of top-down CRPG popularized by things like Rogue, Nethack, Angband, etc., this one's a no-brainer. It's like any of those standard dungeon crawls had been transplanted to a bizarre far-future setting with actual lore and quality-of-life features, while losing none of the humor or difficulty. 

Humanity as we know it has ceased to be, leaving behind mutated remnants, wasteland wanderers, and cybernetics-worshipping transhuman cultists (these comprise the playable characters). The rest of the world is filled out by sentient plants and animals, exceedingly confused robots, monstrosities out of a fever-dream, and the ever-present hints of a great civilization to which Something Happened, once upon a time.

Within the first hour of gameplay I was intentionally ignored by a quest-giving NPC, who was more interested in muttering about electronics than in giving me work. I discovered that I had somehow achieved +300 reputation with the faction of Dogs, who will permit me in their holy places. This seems right and accurate. And, while wandering,  I found a hat covered in snails (which, evidently, grants +250 rep with all mollusks when worn). I've never yet met a snail in-game, but I am sure that this will come in useful someday. Better stick it in a box, though. Even leather armor rusts.

The crows are either trying to tell me secrets or they're out of their corvid minds. They're crows. It may be a little of both. I met an old hermit who greeted me with pleasantries and then proceeded to declare war on a day-glo cat for walking through his garbage pit. I conducted a sacred water exchange ritual with a weird old man, who then proceeded to teach me of the wilderness. My shoes make lizards like me. Plants, though? Nah. Don't even get me started on the qudzu. 

My first run ended after several successful quests because I misjudged a location, stepped into a 4-layer pit, and trapped myself in a pool of salt-water with a bunch of giant, eyeless crabs. Up to then I thought I had been doing quite well.

Suffice it to say: There are a lot of Rogue-like CRPGs on the market. There are NOT a lot of Rogue-like CRPGS that are THIS WEIRD. If you're looking for something with variety, engaging gameplay, and a world that fills your head with question marks, give this one a shot.

185889744.review:
Eine Meisterwerk der Indie-Spielewelt – absolut empfehlenswert!

Caves of Qud ist ein echtes Juwel unter den Indie-Spielen. Was dieses Spiel besonders auszeichnet, ist die außergewöhnlich schöne Grafik, die jeden Bildschirm in ein Kunstwerk verwandelt. Die Entwickler haben hier mit viel Liebe zum Detail eine Welt erschaffen, die nicht nur optisch beeindruckt, sondern auch atmosphärisch tief eintauchen lässt.  

Die Spielmechaniken sind ebenso herausragend – tiefgründig, komplex. Ob man strategisch plant, Ressourcen sammelt oder die Fähigkeiten seines Charakters ausbaut, jede Entscheidung fühlt sich bedeutungsvoll und lohnend an. 

Ein weiteres Highlight ist die prozedural generierte Open World. Jeder Durchgang ist einzigartig, und die Welt lädt regelrecht dazu ein, immer weiter zu erkunden. Es gibt immer etwas Neues zu entdecken, und die Vielfalt der Landschaften, Höhlen und Geheimnisse sorgt dafür, dass die Spannung nie nachlässt.  

Dieses Spiel ist ein Muss für Fans von Abenteuer- und Erkundungsspielen. Die Kombination aus Grafik, Spielmechanik und unendlicher Entdeckungsmöglichkeiten macht Caves of Qud zu einem unvergesslichen Erlebnis.  

10/10 – Absolute Kaufempfehlung!

If you like classic roguelikes at all; CoQ is maybe the best one I've ever played.
Post apoc. It has swords and lasers. Mutants and cybernetics. Talk to a tree or a clam. Try to drink the energy of a star.
If rogues are too hard, the game also has full achievement unlocked easier modes with checkpoints, or non-hostile.

Excellent combination of random, semi-random, and planned events for a play-through. At least 3 endings, if you manage to live that long. Every run is different though. Knowledge + planning + adaptability (+ luck) for the win.

Insane depth and character customisation, introduced slowly as to not be completely overwhelming

Graphical overlay for the classic ascii is superb. Lots of tricks with color and animation help with understanding the situation, and also do some excellent special effects without also losing that classic roguelike vibe.

Caves of Qud is weird and hard, and fabulously excellent. 
It presents an intimidating amount of choice from the start, which only grows as you progress. It doesn't look pretty, everything about the world will kill you, and most of the lore is esoteric or auto-generated at the beginning of the seed. 
But not everything is randomly generated, and as you learn more you'll go from dying before you make it to the first quest objective to being able to pursue a very silly idea to its' end. 

The overwhelming depth of Qud is a consequence of its' many well-designed and predictable systems interacting with equally many hilariously broken and random ones. Destroying the economy can become a routine early-game task, and if you know how to rush then powerful defensive equipment is guaranteed. 

Only play on classic permadeath. or you'll rob yourself.

185647099.review:
Simply one of the best games one can play.

I wasn't sure when to write a review for this game, and I don't think 40 hours of playtime is enough to warrant a fair review due to the hundreds, if not thousands of hours worth of content that's available in the game, but I figured I'd just add to the positive reception Qud has.

Every playthrough of Qud is COMPLETELY different, generating history and creatures/people of legend with actual meaning and impact on the world with each new world the player generates, similar to something like Dwarf Fortress. What sets Qud aside though, is the fact that there's a main storyline keeping everything grounded and giving the player many handwritten adventures to pursue in-between, or as a main focus, their own unique adventure. Each playthrough tells a story of tragedy or triumph, and each playthrough can last anywhere between 30 seconds and 1,000+ hours.

What's unique about Qud, and sorely missing from modern games that rely heavily on procedural generation (think Starfield, No Man's Sky, etc.), is that procedural generation in Qud doesn't *always* feel like procedural generation. Admitidly, sometimes it is obvious, like in the case of generated quests, but the player will come across generated people and creatures of legend, similarly legendary weapons and gear, and even locations with deep history and mysteries to discover completely unique to the singular playthrough - all of which mentioned is procedurally generated and VAST. There's gotta be an infinite amount of ways the world and its lore can be generated in this game.

Not to mention the builds. Hitting the random button in character creation is the best way to play this game (as long as one is only playing permadeath) as pretty much every build is viable in some compacity and has their own challenges and playstyles. Character builds are just another thing that feel infinite and ever-changing. For those who want a more laid back playthrough, though, one can create their own character from scratch and play a gamemode with autosaving and more akin to the Elder Scrolls in terms of sticking to one character for a long period of time without the concern of permanently losing the character on death.

With a massive, sprawling and breathing world, turn-based combat mechanics that keep the player on the edge of their seats in heated and unfair battles, and infinite amount of storytelling capabilites, Caves of Qud is a game that I honestly believe should be played by everyone at least once. The price may seem expensive for this type of game (based off the screenshots, I guess) but in my opinion, there's hundreds of dollars worth of time and content here on an unprecedented level.

11/10. One of the most mind blowing and rewarding games I've ever played where I never feel like I'm wasting my time. The modding community for this game is on another level as well, though I only recommend really digging into mods after a few serious vanilla playthroughs as there's really no need for mods in order to enjoy what this game offers.

185604391.review:
This is a traditional roguelike with basic core interactions. You fight enemies by walking your sprite into theirs and trading attacks until one of you dies. You might occasionally throw a grenade you found, or use a psychic power you developed, or activate a weapon ability you learned. You must explore the open world to find weapons, armor, and artifacts to add to your toolkit. 

It's the world you're exploring that makes this game a singular experience. The action of time has eroded history down to myth, and it's up to you to piece together a coherent context for the things you're seeing. There is an established lore, and a main quest to follow that will lead you to fantastic and eerie places. Overall the game's systems come together to create an immersive adventure that makes you feel like you're in a weird, high-concept science fantasy novel. 

I recommend playing on Roleplay mode.

This game scratches several big itches for me:
- Exploration
- Looting, taking everything that's not nailed down to sell
- Extremely powerful synergies, sometimes to the point of breaking the game
- A vast amount of things to learn in order to master
- Exploring an alien-feeling world, replete with culture, lore, and language
- Lots of small details, sometimes where you least expect them

I've finally completed the game, and this review is part of my way of dealing with a surprisingly profound loss of my character. If you want to learn the game, play with saving and loading enabled. Once you attain some level of mastery, play the intended way--permadeath! It makes the game stick with you longer.

9.5/10 game of all time, it's difficult to learn, the control scheme is ancient, it doesn't have the prettiest graphics (I like them still, though, and they don't detract from getting sucked into the world!), and there's five trillion ways of dying to things that feel unfair, but still, I love this game with all my heart. 185424348.review:
I rarely write Steam reviews as I'm both lazy and busy. But this game deserves to make you get up and write one – it's just that good. It completely pulls you into its atmosphere and leaves you in awe. The world of Qud is unlike anything you've seen before – it mixes post-apocalyptic sci-fi with fantasy in such a unique way, with fascinating lore that makes you want to discover more. Sure, it looks simple, but the mechanics are incredibly deep and meaningful.

What I love most about this game is how it fits any lifestyle – you can binge play for an entire evening or just jump in for a quick session. Being turn-based means there's no rush, but every step counts! You need to think through your battles or figure out how to escape from weird creatures that can drain half your XP. Yes, it's complex, but it doesn't test your reflexes – it's all about knowledge, with a bit of luck thrown in, just like real life!

Important tip: Make sure to install the tutorial mod – it really helps you get started!

I definitely recommend this game to everyone, whether you're a busy parent or a busy gamer – it has something for anyone. I'm probably just scratching the surface here with my 20 hours (which is actually quite a lot for me)!

And here's a bonus – it works flawlessly on Steam Deck or with a gamepad for an amazing couch experience! But if you're a keyboard nerd, this game is perfect – it has vim-style hjkl keys support right out of the box, and you can play the whole thing without touching your mouse!

This is honestly the most intricate and interesting RPG I've played in a long time.

185208660.review:
I’ve been playing RPGs since the days of Ultima, and to me Caves of Qud feels like it captures that same spirit of discovery and freedom—while standing firmly in a league of its own. This game is weird in the best possible way, offering an endlessly imaginative world packed with challenges and surprises around every corner.

The first thing to know is that Caves of Qud doesn’t hold your hand. It throws you into a brilliant mix of predetermined and procedurally generated landscape and expects you to figure things out on your own. The game can be brutal—whether you're in classic permadeath mode or roleplay mode, where the focus shifts to building relationships and navigating the complex world. Either way, every decision matters, and even the smallest misstep can lead to disaster. It’s tough, but the satisfaction of overcoming its challenges makes it all worthwhile.

One of the most exciting aspects of the game is how customizable your character can be. Want to sprout multiple heads or breathe fire? You can. Prefer to augment your PG's body with cybernetic limbs or parts? Go right ahead. The sheer amount of available mutations and cybernetic implants allows for a level of creativity in character building that’s almost unmatched. These aren’t just gimmicks—they genuinely affect how you approach the game’s challenges and interact with its strange world. And they can get you out of troubles much faster.

The game’s graphical style might be a hurdle for some. It’s minimalist (not as in the earlier version of the game, but still...) and text-heavy, relying on your imagination to bring its bizarre world to life. At first, I wasn’t sure if I’d like it, but the more I played, the more I came to appreciate how much the simplicity lets your mind fill in the gaps. Over time, the game’s environments, characters, and stories feel more vivid than anything hyper-realistic graphics could achieve.

The real heart of Caves of Qud is its world. It’s richly layered with ancient ruins, sentient plants, bizarre creatures, and strange factions. Every area you explore feels like it has a history waiting to be uncovered. The writing is sharp and filled with personality—it can be funny, tragic, or downright strange, sometimes all at once.

And yet, I barely scratched the surface of the game. I still don't know what to expect from the mid- and end-game. But I can't wait.

If you’re the kind of player who loves experimenting, exploring, and embracing the unexpected, this game will hook you. It’s an experience that rewards curiosity, creativity, and resilience in ways that few games can match.

185200750.review:
Caves of Qud is the kind of more classic-leaning Roguelike that I'd been waiting for. It is a really challenging and deeply thought out RPG with a unique vibe. The ambient music and the poetic language put a spell on me when I'm playing, and I can get lost for hours just delving into ruins and caverns. 

There's a layer of joyful silliness over the whole thing, though the overall setting is hostile and dangerous; random things will happen that will tickle your imagination, you'll find generated texts that make you laugh out loud, a split-second decision will obliterate an entire town, or some absolute BS will kill you dead in one f****** turn.

This game is for fans of pulp science fiction and post-apocalyptic settings, with each new character bringing a generated history to uncover and fresh set of challenges. Mutated humans and cyborgs live alongside sentient plants, animals and robots, new cultures built in layers atop long-lost civilisations. The bow and sword-wielding knight you just made to take on the Salt Desert and Jungle Ruins could stumble across a bundle of Weird Tubes (equally likely to be a folding chair or a rocket launcher), an ancient library of nonsense, a colony of peaceful, sentient bugs, or in one case, a Legendary fish called Anus... All the while joined by your neo-pronoun-having sentient vine comedian friend. 

It's sword and sorcery for people who love Mad Max and Fallout.

Though the minimalist graphical presentation and flowery prose make the game seem impenetrable, the basics really are quite easy to grasp (with some practice). With the v1.0 release, there is a simple tutorial, the UI and control scheme has been simplified (with multiple options), and if you're afraid of losing a save in Classic mode, you can take on Roleplay Mode (with saving in settlements) or Wander (less hostile creatures). Taking the time to examine elements of the environment really lets you get a feel for what you're seeing on screen, and it gets my imagination running in ways other games don't.

It might take you longer than 2 hours to find the joy of it all, or it might click straight away, so it might be a gamble if you're prone to refunding stuff after trying it. I still recommend Caves of Qud heartily. It keeps calling me back...

185117865.review:
Caves of Qud is an RPG roguelike with beautiful pixel graphics, turn-based gameplay, and strong RNG elements. Some of those words might scare you, so it's worth unpacking. 

It is a true roguelike in the sense that there is no metaprogression. You develop your gameplay by developing your understanding of the game world and mechanics. It is an RPG through-and-through. There is a strong, compelling central storyline, and many side quests and activities to carry you through. The campaign storyline will take you dozens of hours to complete your first go round, many of those hours spent carefully navigating hostile retrofuturistic maps filled with oozes, robots, mutants, and fellow explorers. As you play through the game, you will find yourself creating your own stories, quests, and content naturally, as any good open-world game tends to do.

The RNG is core to the game. More than anything else, Qud is a simulation. The RNG is not punishing, arbitrary, or punitive. You don't feel like you're getting hosed by dice rolls. Almost everything in the game world is randomized each time you play, from the locations of certain powerful enemies (with powerful loot to match), to the relationships between the NPCs you encounter along the way. The RNG keeps the game compelling and fresh, and makes every run exciting, and there are just enough fixed points in the world to give you familiar benchmarks and anchors to guide your play. 

The magic of Qud to me, however, is in how these elements come together. You really feel like you can do almost anything in Qud. Sure, grab a sword, shield, and laser rifle and go through the great Salt Desert killing raiders and seeking caravans. Or sprout a few more arms than you'd expect and wield a half dozen laser pistols. That's fun, too.  But why not get weird with it? 

Become a door by imbuing one with sentience with spray-a-brain and them dominating it with your psychic mutation. Convince an army of goats to follow you around, destroying any who cross you. Inhabit the mind of a leech and go slug it up in the deep jungle. Befriend two horses, name them Horse 1 and Horse 2, load them up with all your valuable loot, and gasp as you watch them both get sucked into different spacetime vortexes, transported to random locations anywhere in Qud taking your loot with them (ask me how I know that last one). 

The turn-based gameplay is fascinating from a software engineering perspective. Each game turn advances the simulation a different amount depending on what the player did. The entire game is played from the perspective of the player, but the simulation takes different perspectives into account. Every creature has stats like Quickness and Movement Speed that determine how long it takes them to accomplish an action, and this interacts with your characters' own stats in interesting ways. Let's say you're dueling it out with a fellow scavenger in the salt desert. You both draw knives, but you distort time around you with your psychic mutations - meaning that you're getting two or three knife attacks in each time the hapless scavenger gets a single attack off. The game feels subtly different each playthrough depending on your build, even if you choose the same weapons. How powerful you feel very much depends not only on your build - but your enemies, and how their builds interact with yours. 

From a development and design perspective the game is a masterpiece. This is an obscenely polished piece of software. The aesthetic and art are simply stunning - the amount of feeling and depth the team's artists gave everything from tiles to two-headed hogs using only a few pixels is incredible. The music is exactly what it should be - compelling and enhancing, informative and rich, but not overbearing. The game mechanics work together in intuitive ways that not only allow, but encourage and foster, spontaneous discovery. If you think two things should work together a certain way - they probably do. And it's probably hilarious. The modding community is thriving and embraced by the devs. This is a game made with love by people who love games.

Qud is truly unique. If you like roguelikes, RPGs, and procedural generation, this game is simply a must-get. It's worth every penny.

185117621.review:
This game is not what it sells itself to be. There are some things you should know before purchasing. Browsing through the positive Steam reviews, there is a lot of undeserved praise which I feel the need to dispel.

This game is like playing DnD under a dungeon master (DM) who has one campaign with the same main quest and same main characters and same world map and same key items etc every time. These elements are NOT procedurally generated. The only procedurally generated elements are minutiae that you wouldn't care about anyway-- like random dice rolls, and the specific layout of battle areas, number of enemies, etc. The same enemies are encountered in the same locations in the world, and their loot tables are pretty rigid. Even the locations that the main quest-givers send you to are the same, and even the important encounters in those areas are the same. Heck, the DM even set things up so that you will likely contract a disease ("glotrot") from a specific place during a specific quest. Even that level of detail is micromanaged. Would you enjoy playing under such a DM? 

The game design is internally strained. It's trying to sell a replayable roguelike experience when all it has to work with is a single campaign. That might have been possible, but the details which matter are railroaded. You're expected to memorise where all the traps are, literally and figuratively, and to account for them next time. You're expected to get through this DM's campaign no matter how many times you have to try. And don't go thinking you can come at it with your own playstyle or role play in this role-playing game, no no no! For my first run, I chose to be a psychic merchant. I had plans to travel the world and accumulate expensive gadgets and equipment through trade, and to recruit bodyguard companions. Turns out that it's not actually a viable option to play a character with a low Toughness stat-- you will get one-shotted by things in the starting area in a way that is completely outside your control (even if you proceed gingerly!). And for some [i]terrible[/i] reason, the player is treated as the centre of the world: enemies will almost always make a beeline for you, even if you have three companions. The enemy AI is primitive, and this makes this play style untenable.

Going into it, I thought this game was about role-play, lore and a narrative-rich world. Bzzt. No it isn't. The lore is procedurally generated garbage-- it often doesn't even have correct grammar. It's like reading bad fiction from someone who wants to sound smart so they use lots of big words they've heard before without knowing their meanings (or in some cases, whether they're a noun or a verb etc.).

Since role-playing is not a real option, this just leaves the roguelike elements, combat and 'instrumental play'. Well then, you should know that some starting mutations are just better than others, and not to waste your time on psychic abilities. Why? Because if you spec into melee, then you can use your raw strength every single turn without a cooldown (attacking with a melee weapon). If you spec into psychic abilities, then you need to wait... something like 50 or 100 turns between attacks! That is just as unplayable as it sounds. Also, the inventory management is really tedious. It takes way too many clicks / keystrokes to do simple things. 

But this isn't a great roguelike either. In roguelike games, you're supposed to have the opportunity to choose between alternatives as a way for the player to exercise their agency and build a strategy based on the random elements of the run. For example, giving the player a choice between three items. In this game, that role is accomplished by "unidentified trinkets/artefacts". However, they are [i]unidentified[/i] in stores, so you can't know what you're choosing. That's flawed game design. (One exception: you can ask Tinker merchants to identify their items first, but that is not-at-all obvious in the UI.) And the most important items (like mechanical wings and "recoilers") are in fixed locations or are predictable/manipulable so that you can reliably obtain them. 

The game is also a bit buggy: I checked the option to only colour character sprites according to their damage taken, but this setting is not respected. Then there are enemies that are "hostile" but won't actually attack the character. 

So what is this game? Who is it for? The game isn't designed properly as a roguelike. But it isn't a great role-playing game either because it isn't balanced to allow the full gamut of play styles which it supposes to accomodate in the character creation menu. I don't know who this is for. It is one of the most bizarre games that I have played. Unfortunately, I don't mean that in an entirely positive sense.

-----

I don't mind magniloquent writing when it's done well. If I have to look up words and I find the writing satisfying, then great. Unfortunately, I think the various descriptions in this game are just bad writing. I think it's generated by a large language model with minimal oversight.

- Description of an enemy called a twinning lamprey: "A ribbon of scaleless tissue quivers in suspension beyond a mouth ringed with repeating triangle teeth. It extrudes a double through the mirrored planes of reality."
This looks like an eel-like enemy. Why would you say the body of the eel is "beyond" the mouth? That implies that the mouth comes first in some way. That doesn't make sense. And what does it mean to extrude "a double", let alone "through the mirrored planes of reality"?

 - Description of an enemy called a plastronoid: "Chrome rondures sling themselves along the orbital paths of an invisible magnetic gyroscope. By inscrutable intervals, one pops out the transverse plane with violent momentum."
I think that should say "at" inscrutable intervals, and "its" transverse plane. Not to mention the other problems with this.

 - Description of an enemy called a snailmother: "Out a pristine shell of rolling citrine, frozen azure, and polished jade, the goopy neck cranes straight up and loosens a throbbing egg from her gelatin clutch."
After looking words up, it turns out that "citrine" in noun form refers to a yellow-coloured variety of quartz, and "azure" is an obsolete way to refer to lapis lazuli (a blue-coloured mineral). What does it mean for the citrine to be "rolling", or the azure "frozen"? Why is the jade polished specifically but not the other two minerals? Here's a better description I'm writing on-the-spot: "This mollusc is housed by a multicoloured shell of minerals: orange, blue and green."
 
- Description of an enemy called a Mechanimist rummager: "His hunch-back is meadowed in tattered robes the color of slate. Strands of matted chin hair splay against his chapped lips, and his eyes dart at nearish trinkets."
According to the Webster's 1913 unabridged dictionary, "meadow" is not a verb. And if it is to be used as one, then tell me what it means for a hunch back to be meadowed in tattered robes. This is nonsense. Now the sprite doesn't show the mechanimist having a hunch-back whatsoever, so this description is just false. Also it says "strands of matted chin hair". Is it just a few strands or is it so much that it's capable of being matted?! It makes no sense. And how can chin hair splay against the lips? That seems implausible. Also the mechanimist has no visible hair: he looks to be wearing a mask and hood. Maybe that should have been mentioned in the worded description?

185107007.review:
A turn-based Souls-like with permadeath.

This game is perfect for those who enjoy a real challenge. The combat mechanics are reminiscent of a strategic board game, providing plenty of depth. Be ready to invest hundreds (or even thousands) of hours facing repeated deaths. To make progress easier, explore resources like QudZoo, the Caves of Qud Wiki, or watch YouTube guides. Even with these aids, expect to spend dozens of hours learning through trial and error.

For beginners, starting in Roleplay mode is highly recommended. It lets you respawn at your last checkpoint, easing the learning curve without diminishing the experience. Also, don’t forget to press L to inspect unfamiliar enemies. If an enemy is marked as "Tough" or stronger and your build isn’t solid, you’ll likely face a swift death.

Quick tip: AP = Armor Points in this game. If the penetration value exceeds the armor points, the attacker gets an extra damage roll. The extra damage is calculated as one roll multiplied by (penetration - armor points).

One downside is that the pricing is on the higher end of the spectrum, especially for players in Asian countries.

Looking forward to my next 100+ hrs. I will spend with this absolute gem of a game.

Technically: graphics are simple, yet detailed in a distinct retro way. The soundtrack is great and athmospheric, and it will probably run on a potato with a VGA port.

You ever have a friend that plays some random game for endless hours and you just don't get it? Maybe it's Runescape, Mount & Blade or Victoria. Well, this is one of those games. You either love it or you don't and I can't imagine there being a large amount of in-between because the truth of the matter is not everyone wants to invest in combat where 2 jpegs dry hump each other while numbers pop up, so I get it.

However, if you can look past that what you have is a really fun open ended exploration game with an extremely good sense of discovery. It's the kind of game you slap on a playlist and explore with whatever abomination you decided to be. Maybe it's a 5 limbed flying monster with freeze ray eyes or a dagger wielding mutant ninja turtle that expels sleeping gas. 

It's entirely up to you and the freedom of it all is what makes it great.


Now if you want my advice on it. I would say buy it and if in the first hour and  a half  you're not sold on it, then refund it through steam because I doubt it will change your opinion if you don't like the initial experience. Sure, the more you play it does get better but only if you like the foundational concepts.

184933159.review:
This one here is a gem with loads of content, extremely well done and revamped procedurally generated histories, dungeons, factions etc. It is an incredibly deep game with immersive lore, soundtrack, environments and world interactions.

These aspects make the world feel alive and keeps you wondering what you will see next. Will your pet from the beginning of the game sacrifice themselves for you in the depths of a cave only for you to barely escape and meet a dog (also the mayor of a town) and giant sentient dragonfly to accompany you on your adventure?

Or will you wander into a weird farm where the plants have symbiotically taken over most of the villagers and also worship a bowl that signifies their dedication to the Horned One (whoever that is)? Will you use so much psychic energy as a mutant that an inter-dimensional being is alerted to your presence?

Will you be a cybernetic pure blood or a mutated human with sensory bulbs growing from your face?

I could keep going, but this game is packed with a bunch of random but awesome emergent stories and events. It's packaged nicely into a title with charming retro graphics, lots of attention to detail and difficult but rewarding gameplay.

Highly recommend.

184902094.review: There's simply nothing like it. As a work of fiction it's dense, mesmerizing, and absolutely enthralling. The story and world are drawing on a long history of Sci-fi and Fantasy goodness steeped in a truly unique and otherworldly funk that sticks firmly in your mind as unmistakably bizzare. As a videogame the absolutely swirling abyss of game interactions and mechanical layers reveal new things about the world to even the most seasoned players. Often with lethal and hilarious results. This game is a miraculous labor of love and has a little something anyone ready for a deep, evocative, and complex RPG they can play at their pace, their way. You could turn on Roleplay mode and take a methodical narrative approach to learning the ropes. You could play Wander mode and immerse yourself in the massive layered world building. You could play Classic mode and throw yourself into a chaotic and tense culmination of some of the Classic Rogulike Genres best conventions and features filed to a razor point. It's maddening, cozy, slime drenched goodness and well worth the time you put into unraveling its world.

184816276.review:
I'm surprised that I'm leaving a negative review on this one. In theory it's right up my alley. It receives a ton of praise from the oldschool roguelike enthusiasts and supposedly has really good writing.

I like a lot about the game. I like the world, I like the music, I like the themes and I like the setting. It has a ton of really cool stuff and tons of ways to "break" it with clever thinking. You can swap bodies with creatures, bypass large quests to acquire early power, clone items and even yourself. There's dozens of hours of content with several different builds or playstyles for you to enjoy. But honestly?

[h3]It's just so incredibly boring and tedious[/h3]
The [b]constant[/b] Inventory management. The caves and ruins that overstay their welcome by nearly 10-20 floors, the never-ending interruptions on the worldmap that force you to wander around killing trivial enemies for 5 minutes at a time. It's all so incredibly tedious. I am perpetually in a state of doing things that I do not want to do just to actually accomplish my desired goal at any point in time.

Yes, a lot of what I just listed can be avoided or mitigated by just adjusting how you play the game. Don't like the loot management? Simply loot less stuff. You don't "need" money so the constant looting isn't necessary. Don't like how long ruins/caves are? Simply do not enter them. The worldmap? There's a skill and some items that can improve that.

However it just feels so incredibly backwards. The game presents me with things that I should want to do, and then makes them feel bad to actually interact with. Then it provides me with tools or realizations that solve those problems. I should [b]want[/b] to explore ruins. I should [b]want[/b] to loot items. But the game makes me hate doing that and essentially tells me to turn those features off.

Many of the endgame areas and enemies are also extremely unfun to fight against. The zones are a very clunky maze that requires tons of backtracking and circling around to actually progress in. There are almost no enemies either making the entire area a massive slog. You could try and dig through the walls but then you'll spawn evil clones of yourself that are essentially guaranteed to kill you. When you finally [i]do[/i] see a normal enemy, it's something with an impenetrable forcefield that has infinite armor and can only be killed with a very specific strategy. What's that, your character doesn't want to use EMP grenades and disintegration tactics? [i]Then you simply aren't going to be killing this enemy.[/i]

[h3]The game has [i]Horrendous[/i] Pacing[/h3]
Early game you are very weak and very easily killed. It takes a few runs to just get a character stable enough to survive to actually start the main story. Once you do though, you're almost guaranteed to succeed because power creep is out of control. By the time you reach the midgame you are likely already well on your way to being an unstoppable god, and have completed all of your desired character progression.

Then you get to the endgame and they're like, we need to you explore around the highest level areas and acquire components so that we can craft you an unstoppable companion that will be with you for the rest of the game! Like brother I don't need that just let me fight the big bad guy or whatever. This is the kind of quest that would have been perfect in the earlier stages of the game but are just so unnecessary by that point that it feels like an massive chore.

Qud just has too much "fluff" content that takes up your time--and when you finally get to the "good parts" you're already mostly checked out. As crazy as it sounds for a game like this, the experience would have been [i]significantly[/i] better if it was linear and more railroaded.

[h3]There are almost no interesting encounters[/h3]
Despite unique enemies and legendary creatures existing, there is almost nothing that feels like an actual "boss fight" or something that puts the culmination of all of your character progression on the line. There are no tense moments, no strategic use of your abilities to maximize your combat potential for a tough enemy.

You press the same buttons you always press, in the same order you always press them, and you win. Easily.
...unless it's the random pyramid enemy in a high level area. Then you throw your build in the trash and use the exact same character-agnostic "tactic" that everyone uses, get nothing for your trouble, and then move on with your day.

There's no special unique items that change how your character plays, and there isn't any [i]need[/i] for them either because nothing actually challenges you. It's just not interesting.

[hr][/hr]
I think caves of qud has the bones of something good. It has a ton of really solid mechanics and cool interactions between them. There's fun ways to break it and in theory there are fun ways for it to break you. The soundtrack is great and there's a palpable sense of wonder and mystery about nearly everything in the world. But the game is bogged down by poor pacing. It is bogged down by poor balance. It is bogged down by tedium.

There are a couple of mods that can drastically improve your experience with this game (namely anything that removes inventory weight and adds new content), but it's honestly just not enough. Caves of Qud just kind of sucks to play.

184813783.review:
Imagine you have suddenly awoken inside the most unimaginably complex Swiss watch ever. You are surrounded by hundreds of interlaced gears, your eyes see springs winding and unwinding all around you, and everywhere there are ticking sounds beating to different rhythms. In fact, the very place you stand is moving, but you can't even tell in which direction. You will be completely disoriented, overwhelmed, and unable to function as your eyes can barely find something stable to look at, much less stand upon. You aren't even sure where the walls are or if you're in the middle of a kaleidoscopic hall of mirrors.

However, if you can take several deep breaths and get over the shock, you will be awed. You can't help but be swept away by how utterly fascinating your environment is. One wrong step, one misunderstanding among 100 misunderstandings you don't even know you misunderstand.. and you will be crushed. But the wonder is there. You don't even know what this thing is capable of, and once you think you do, there's still more to find out.

Do you like text adventures? Did you enjoy MUDs and their ilk? If you can appreciate strange and deep turn-based role playing games, if you like exploring and experimenting, and if you enjoy interfaces which are richly adorned piles of words, then this game is well worth it. The quality of life changes that have been added in the past year and up to its 1.0 release make it much more accessible and easier to recommend than ever before.

Watch some video guides or read some introductions to the game to help you if you're utterly confounded, as there are some reliably safe starting steps to take. They will at least give you some solid purchase as you start to wander, get lost, and try to find patterns in the movements of the insanely complicated, intricate machine that is this game.

184785882.review:
This is an utterly fascinating game with a vast sandbox of interactions and interesting mechanics... but it is a sandbox that doesn't paticularly seem concerned with quality gameplay. It's definetely not a case of "wide as an ocean, shallow as a puddle". Rather... let me give the example that made me choose to quit.

I was facing a dungeon of my level, that NPCs recommended to get some cold resistance for. Unfortuantely, no aspect of the game actually tells you how you can get that resistance, so I went in with what little I had. After facing a boss that was weirdly overpowered for what was supposed to be my level and cheesing it by spending a hundred turns gunning at it from a distance it wouldn't respond to, I eventually made it to a floor harboring two special types of enemies in paticular.
One had a freeze ray that seemed to be a guaranteed hit that would stunlock you for a good 60 rounds (less with that cold resistance I still don't know how to get), which is several times more than enough time for it to just walk up and nibble you for a guaranteed death.
The second came in pairs, and if you kill one, the other instantly respawns it at full health. To defeat it, you must either kill both in the same turn (requiring you to finagle them to low health and finish them with an AoE, which you may simply not have), or use Normality Gas on them (which is a very specific thing you probably don't have), or stun one with other specific abilities or consumables you very well may not have. The game threw 20 of them or so at me, with no information on which are paired up, or any ingame way to know any of the above. I had to wiki and savescum to stand a chance (and did not, because it was 20 and the "you are immune to harmful gases" aspect of my helm mysteriously is useless against stun gas grenades)

Between stuff like that, certain enemies being able to straight up remove limbs permanently on hit, and the damage mechanics allowing for unlikely extreme spikes of damage, I'm suprised this is typically played as a roguelike. Even the "roleplay" mode where you can save in towns can easily have deaths undo an hour of progress or more, which you are *unable* to get back as the places you were at are rerolled - sometimes into nonexistance.

It takes a specific kind of person to enjoy a game that can undo loads of progress on a whim like this, with nothing to show for it except maybe knowing what the BS smells like for next time so that you can cheese it before it cheeses you.

It's a nice looking ASCII art-ish game, but suffers from clarity and control issues. This makes the game feel archaic and arcane in nature.

Clunky and cumbersome controls make the game tiresome to play, especially as someone using a 60% keyboard. Having to constantly switch from mouse controls in one instance and then to keyboard controls in the next just to maneuver the map is needlessly exhausting and constantly disturbs the flow of concentration.

The UI is unclear and confusing. The sprites feel way too small and make it hard to distinguish what is the map/environment and what isn't. That in conjunction with the status effects and liquid system make it even more difficult to tell things apart. This is very bad when it comes to combat - you really have to squint and pay attention. Many times I wasn't realizing I was in a lethal situation.

Any potential appreciation I could have had for the depth of the story/setting and/or mechanics was made impossible because of these issues. I love story rich games. But this one ain't it. Too much of a hassle.

184605204.review:
In a word: engrossing. Not just fun to play (though certainly it is that), but not since Morrowind have I been so absolutely engrossed in a world this alien and fascinating.

I fell in love with science fiction and fantasy as a child because those genres have the capacity to tell stories that both encourage and challenge the imagination. "Out of this world" stories. These days it seems like the kind of fiction that should be about telling stories of the unreal and fantastical are more about recycling well-trodden and comfortable tropes; bland flavorless mush that is nonetheless soothing as an escape. Caves of Qud doesn't just present a broadly appealing world, but a very unique one at that.

The world is rich, and one that you can't help but want to sink your teeth into. The history of the world is oblique, but the mystery makes it all the more compelling to discover. The people have strange and sometimes bizarre customs, the struggle for survival isn't quite like any other game I've ever played, and personhood is extended to humans, robots, animals, plants, and animated objects.

Nearly 20 hours in and I feel like I've only barely just scratched the surface. Sometimes when you see a game has overwhelmingly positive reviews it's for a VERY good reason. Caves of Qud is one of those games.

Live and drink. [End]

184484689.review:
I'll describe the first play session where this game truly clicked for me. Created a character using the daily run option on the last day of 2024. [i]Note: mild spoilers below.[/i]

[h2]How it started[/h2]
My profession is tinkerer and I started with very little combat proficiency, but a mutation allowing me to clone myself. Early on I figured out that by keeping my inventory stocked with grenades, essentially every time I was in a pinch I could create a clone and run the other direction, hoping not to get caught in the barrage of acid, ice, and fire. Best of all, [i]real me[/i] keeps the grenades. Definitely got frozen by [i]other me[/i] a few times.

Eventually realized that my physical mutation -- horns -- was more powerful than most of my other weapons so I started leaning into that and seeing real success in hand-to-hand combat.

One day as I was journeying through the hills, I encountered a cave that was not only deep, but incredibly expansive. I spent literal days exploring it and got tons of experience and items, really started settling into a rhythm. Eventually I realized -- I had no idea how I was going to get out of this place. Then, as I was descending yet another level, I ran into the most difficult encounter yet. In the middle of it was a spacetime vortex. I said screw it, entered the vortex and got teleported to an isolationist settlement of centaurs.

[i]unspoilered: I did something awesome and unexpected at the centaur village.[/i]
[spoiler]Now, normally these druids disallow outside visitors but they were right in the middle of unraveling a heist and needed help from "kendren", or people like me. I said hell yes I'll solve your mystery. After a very real and professional investigation, I pinned the blame on their despot which overthrew the incumbent government and installed a democratic leader. Queue me riding off into the sunset.[/spoiler]
I felt like such a badass.

[h2]Disaster strikes[/h2]
As I was journeying home to turn in my original quest, I felt a tickle in my throat..... and then my tongue rotted and fell off.

It is not hyperbole to say this is catastrophic. I could no longer parlay with local leaders, I could only trade at a serious disadvantage, and worse yet I consumed water (the in-game currency) at about 10x the usual rate as drinking would often cause me to unceremoniously upchuck this most precious resource.

I was at a loss for what to do. Nothing else mattered from this point forward; my only goal from here was to try and salvage this run (did I mention death is permanent?) by curing my glotrot and regrowing my tongue. Home would have to wait. After changing course eastward and finding an apothecary, I somehow scrounged together enough dough (read: water) to buy a crash course on healing every sickness under the sun and was able to mix myself a cure for the disease itself. And that was the easy part.

You see, once your tongue has fallen off your options for growing a new one are quite limited. You can either attempt to brute force your way into a *very* dangerous area where a city exists that can allow you to regrow limbs, or you can try to purchase an exceedingly rare tonic that, when applied, will regenerate one single limb.

I searched for *days* to try and find any merchant selling that tonic. I traveled to every caravan I knew of, every village and city, and nobody had it on offer. Regardless, I probably wouldn't have been able to afford it given how much water I wasted by simply existing. Thus, out of other options, I began making my way toward that perilous settlement that promised the possibility of healing. 

As I traveled there, I stumbled across some ruins containing scant more than a single chest. In that chest was the tonic I needed. I couldn't believe it.

Let me tell you, the feeling of satisfaction as I finally dispensed that tonic into my bloodstream and regrew my tongue -- I wish I could bottle how that felt. There are few moments in gaming that I can recall feeling so triumphant. I was BACK! After all that misery, I could finally speak to people again, sell my wares, and resume my quest!

As I started heading home once again, I got into a tussle with a lumberjack robot and it [b]cut my arm off.[/b]



[h2]Closing thoughts[/h2]
So yeah, that's where I'm currently at with this run. I'm about to dive in and play some more. I'll probably find this review in a few years and remember just how awesome it was to finally understand the appeal of games like this.

If you're a fan of games that allow emergent storytelling you're going to be hard-pressed to find one more effective at it than Caves of Qud. It took me a [i]really[/i] long time (originally purchased the game in 2018 I think?) to "see the matrix" so-to-speak, but after getting used to the presentation the game is truly astonishing for its scope and depth. Also, no two runs ever feel whatsoever similar which is a feat on its own. Give it a try if you're in the market for a roguelike or roguelike-adjacent game that you can become completely immersed in.

184368712.review:
It may not look like much initially, but this is a truly incredible game. Let me explain.
My character (a cyborg swordsman named Ruvrin) was on his way to the Six Day Stilt when he got lost in the desert, as often happens in this game. I was immediately ambushed by an army of Isaachari raiders. After easily wiping them all out with my blade, I entered the lair they were protecting. As I turned a corner, confusion seized me and I couldn’t make heads or tails of what was happening around me at all. In my periphery, though, I saw a legendary Isaachari called Flays-in-Oil step forward, throwing slime or some similar substance at me. 

The confusion continued and extended by several turns. Another Isaachari emerged and stabbed me, while Flays-in-Oil dual wielded two bronze daggers, dogpiling the damage on. I finally got the hint it was time to run and sprinted away, up the stairs and back out to the desert. With time the confusion dissipated and I took out the lackey first. Then, Flays-in-Oil followed me into the desert.

I tried to lose him, but he wouldn’t give up easily it seemed. So I decided to get creative and go toe to toe with him, not knowing how to deal with the confusion at all since I was new to the game. The more expansive terrain seemed to help me dodge his confusion attacks (the cramped corridors of his hideout were dangerous because you couldn’t really evade the confusion there).

The ensuing fight between us seemed to go on for in game days. It was a lengthy struggle, only because I realized a sphynx injector on me could help even the playing field for a few moments. That, and healthy use of the sprint mechanic gave me brief openings to get the confusion to wear off, and do damage to Flays-in-Oil. I noticed every time he confused me, the weird substance he threw at me trailed on the ground. By the end of the fight, we were surrounded by massive pools of it in the middle of the desert. I realized that they call him Flays-in-Oil for a reason, which was a fun detail to take in once it dawned on me. I barely survived, and when I landed the killing blow, believe me when I tell you it was the best moment in gaming for me this year. All of this, by the way, did not seem procedurally generated--but it was, which is nuts.

And there have been many other noteworthy randomly generated moments in Caves of Qud since then—once, I infiltrated a legendary cannibal’s lair, and used Rebuke Robot to hack his Drillbot before directing it to massacre him and all his lackeys.

Another time, a village of dung loving dragonflies who had overthrown their dung hating mayor in favor of a scheming crocodile, and who had desecrated statues of the old mayor all over the town after he was overthrown (hilarious), tasked me with stealing a salt mill from a pig farmer. I went to the farm, freed the pigs to distract the farmer, and stole the item from his storage, then gave it to the crocodile as requested. So he could rest on it and use it for warmth, or something to that effect, he said.

Did I mention that this game also has an incredibly well done, pre-made main questline in addition to all this? Because it does. 
Get this game folks. 10/10

Caves of Qud is, at its core, a 2D, roguelike, sci-fi Morrowind on steroids. It has the mysterious atmosphere, esoteric writing, ridiculously fun power scaling, factions & reputation mechanics, and so much more-- I've spent 260 hours and still haven't seen over half of the content here. That might seem a bit much, but I've found Qud veils its vast depths in a mystery that's both enticing & rewarding to learn about slowly, with repetition. Unlike Morrowind, no matter how overpowered you feel your character is, even if you're confidently triple-wielding matter-disintegrating particle rifles and able to bend spacetime to your will, there always seems to be some cosmic horror or sentient chrome pyramid out there that can humble you in a single misstep. It may be frustrating to have a really good run come to an end, but every new run comes with the possibility of discovering more OP combinations and hilariously fortunate (or unfortunate) situations. And if you really just can't get over losing your progress that often, you're given the option to play the game with checkpoints, or without combat at all. Did I mention that Qud plays *amazingly* on a controller? It's truly a marvel how the devs managed to fit all the keybinds you'd need into a gamepad layout! It feels even more convenient than the original numpad control scheme, and I almost exclusively play with a controller now. 

Give Qud a shot. If you can play Baldur's Gate III, I promise you can figure it out in a day or two. Live and drink!

When I started being involved in roguelike development, around 2000, I remember lots of very ambitious projects about games which used the simple presentation and exploration/combat system of roguelikes to challenge the player's imagination and make very complex, simulationist gameplay possible. Like ADOM, but better. Most of these developers never released anything... instead, eventually a counter-movement happened to actually release something, so we got lots of shorter roguelikes, focused on balance, which are great in their own right, but something was missing.

Caves of Qud is like these old dreams, but successful. Very complex. Very epic. Lots of similarities to roguelike classics (the general structure similar to ADOM, figuring out devices like in Alphaman). Amazing worldbuilding and writing. Hopefully it will inspire a new wave of great roguelikes.

184313251.review:
The first thing to understand about Caves of Qud is that it is an RPG. In fact, it might be one of the purest RPGs made, if you look at the roots of the genre as "putting a tabletop RPG experience in your computer." Many people call it a roguelike, but the similarities are very surface-level. Much of the important stuff in the game is not randomly generated and follows standard RPG fare: a campaign (or "main quest"), the general layout of the overworld, the locations of major... locations. You have very standard stats and skill systems (though the skills themselves can be very unique), inventory management is done with weight instead of slots, managing hunger (thirst in this game) is trivial, identifying items is very different than in Rogue, and so on. The game takes inspiration from Rogue, since it was one of the original "put RPG on computer" games, but it does not actually subscribe to its design. If you are not familiar with, used to, or a fan of roguelikes, do not let that stop you from playing this game. Once you get used to the controls, everything else is much closer to a classic RPG than anything.

The next thing to understand is that Qud is an OUTSTANDING RPG. Even without considering the procedural generation, it's a very good experience. The unique setting makes the game very hard to put down; you always want to keep exploring and keep making progress in the main quest to find out more. The writing in the game is a bit flowery at times, but very descriptive and does well to flesh out the world (be sure to Look at everything and everyone and check their descriptions!). The systems of the game are very well balanced, and often have little twists that make you think a bit more than you normally would. Every stat is relevant to any build to some extent. Bartering is done with water, which you need to drink, and which is also considerably heavy, making buying and selling items much more involved than other games. The combat skills you can get are extremely varied, and you can play for a long time just trying different ones and seeing what you can do with them. Siding with factions can get you information, including locations of interest, skills, and recipes, but befriending one group may make another your enemy. Information itself is a currency of sorts that you gather by exploring, and you have to decide carefully who you share it with. It is a little magical how the mechanics and the setting work together so well.

The final thing to understand is that the "roguelike" elements that are in the game exists to boost the RPG experience into a whole new level. Permadeath is a very core aspect of this game. A very significant part of the RPG experience comes from having to put effort into surviving, and actually fearing death. The random generation exists to make the permadeath actually enjoyable. Your main quest may be the same, but the details along the way can vary wildly. Dungeon layouts, quests, the history of the world, the relationships between factions (including you), what legendary items exist and what exactly they are, and more vary wildly. Hell, just the normal items you find at merchants or in dungeons can differ enough to provide varied experiences. The game is constantly throwing new situations at you and asking "what would you do?", which is exactly what an RPG should be doing.

I know this ruins the three part form of this review, but there is one last thing that has to be mentioned that won't fit into any of the other parts. The character creation system is extremely powerful, and it beautifully marries the RPG elements and the "roguelike" elements together. You are given an absolute smorgasboard of choices when creating your character. For instance, all 70+ mutations in the game are available at the start. This helps greatly soften the blow of death. If you are the kind of person who views the game as a challenge to beat, each run is a chance to experiment and optimize your build. If you enjoy roleplaying, you can create all kinds of non-standard characters or themed characters and see how their lives play out. You could opt to randomize certain aspects of your character, and enjoy playing with the hand you're dealt. Hell, go back and forth between playstyles to keep things even more fresh. And if none of that sounds appealing to you, somehow, despite my preaching, that's okay; there is a non-permadeath mode that is still tons of fun, because the game is still a really damn good RPG without it.

184304803.review:
It is 2007, and I am reading a Gene Wolfe novel for the first time. I grip the great volume with both hands and place it on the stand. The androgyne asks if I have seen it previously, and I tell him I have not. I am 30 years old.

It is 1982, and I am staring at a monochrome screen playing Aztec on an Apple II. My father has brought the machine home from work for the weekend, and I am enthralled. I am 5 years old.

It is 2024, and I am writing a review for Caves of Qud. I am struggling to explain the profound and eerie sense that this game was made *specifically for me*, as though it has reached into moments from my past, present, and future, and blended them into this miraculous concoction. I am 47 years old.

It is 1986, and I have discovered a game called Rogue. I have long since mastered the art of parsing these glyphs when I encounter them *linearly*, but these once-familiar symbols are undergoing some strange semiosis in my mind as I decipher their new meanings and portents. I tap, tap, tap the keyboard. I am 9 years old.

It is 2015, and I am playing Caves of Qud for the first time. The theatre of my mind is unfurling, and I sense neither space nor time beyond the bounds of the saltmarsh, and the teeming layers of history that lurk beneath its surface. I prefer the stillness here among the kaleidoscopic bonnets of the Rainbow Wood. I am tired of Earth. I tap, tap, tap the keyboard. I am 38 years old.

184021580.review:
[h1][b]硬核沙盒肉鸽，末世科幻神作[/b][/h1]

[h1]前言[/h1]
《Caves of Qud 卡德洞窟》是一款自由且丰富的开放世界硬核Rogue游戏，本作构建了一个充满了未知和秘密的奇幻世界，玩家可于本作尽情享受角色扮演的乐趣，享受超高自由度带来的畅快体验，享受RogueLike游戏的无穷魅力。

[h1]真正的类Rogue游戏[/h1]
遇事不决做肉鸽，这个品类如今已经成为了最常见的游戏类型，也是大部分游戏开发者和独立爱好者热衷的游戏类型。
但严格来讲市面上流行的多数肉鸽游戏只能称为RogueLite，其节奏更快、难度更低、通常拥有局外成长和辅助选项、地图生成也只是用设计好的素材拼接而成。

自上古鼻祖《Rogue》发布后，其独特的玩法一下子就流行开来，模仿者络绎不绝，最初这些后来者被统称为RogueLike，其遵循着《Rogue》的多数特点，如ASCII字符组合而成的画面、随机生成、永久死亡等。
虽然目前RogueLite正如日中天，但仍有大量开发者坚持着硬核和复古游戏的开发，本作就是诞生于其中的佼佼者。

[h1]多年打磨下的硬核作品[/h1]
这部《Caves of Qud》自2017年发售至今，十几年如一日的保持着更新，其内容丰富度和可玩性已经达到了一个巅峰。
本作构建了一个极其吸引人的末世科幻世界，这里除了人类外还有变异人种，城镇、部落、洞穴、遗迹等数不胜数，各类魔法和高科技道具更是多如牛毛，这些内容共同组合在一起带给人的体验相当独特。

尽管游戏包含一个简短的教程，但也只是教了一点皮毛，游戏中玩家不仅需要时刻关注自己的各项属性，还要依靠策略和经验在危险丛生的敌群中生存、与多个阵容和派系交锋。
游戏中大大小小的事物均可以互动，游戏为其精心安排了文字和描述，玩家可通过阅览这些内容了解这个饱经风霜的世界。
迭代至今，本作的游玩模式已经多达经典、角色扮演、漫步、日常等数个，其中经典模式便是极为硬核的永久死亡模式，角色扮演模式则可以存档读档，更适合新手。

[h1]缺少中文是最大遗憾[/h1]
虽然本作目前在Steam上拥有好评如潮的傲人成绩，但新玩家入坑依然有不少阻力，缺少中文支持便是最直观的那一个。
因为游戏的设计包含了AI生成的文字，本作的汉化一直都是个问题，且发展至今想要完全汉化也是个非常庞大的工程。

目前有个民间汉化，其汉化了界面和游戏中一部分内容，用来入门可以了不至于去啃生肉，但想要完全理解游戏中海量内容还远远不够。
因为目前游戏仍在频繁更新，如果想要体验这个汉化，建议在Steam中将游戏切换到历史版本，汉化包地址在评论区可以看到。

[h1]结语[/h1]
没有精美的画面、整个世界随机生成、多数操作均以文字指令展现，在RogueLike游戏大行其道的如今，《Caves of Qud》仍不忘初心日复一日的更新着，其为大量原教旨主义者带来了成百上千小时的沉浸体验，出色的品质值得每一个喜欢Rogue游戏的玩家去品鉴，只可惜目前汉化还不完善，期待官中到来的那一天。

184016446.review:
[b]9.25/10[/b]

Incredible game. Deep and addictive gameplay mechanics with some identity issues that prevent it from being ONE OF THE GAMES OF ALL TIME. 

[i]I bought this on sale during the 1.0 launch, so all of my thoughts are in the here and now. I never knew this game prior to launch, which is what YOU THIS PERSON LOOKING TO BUY needs to hear![/i]

Alright… So this game looks ugly at first glance. You thought it was weird, I thought it was bad, and my friends judge me harshly whenever I talk about it. But there's something actually magical that happens the more you play it. Whoever made this game is absolutely a back-end software developer who has a repressed gift for UI design. 

When you play this game for an hour, the UI just naturally grafts into your eyes and transposes to your muscle memory. It's incredible… 

Which brings me to the first of only a few criticisms. 

[h2]#1 - It Hurts to Move Sometimes... [/h2]

The controls in this game don't naturally run with WASD, which genuinely screws with my comfort play. You have full control of it. It's not that big of a deal. 

[h3]My biggest issue with this game is what seems to be it's identity crisis. [/h3] 

I'd wager a guess that someone built this as a small-time rogue-like. They then continued to have PROFOUND IDEAS OVER AND OVER to the point that they had developed one of the most fascinating RPGs I've ever seen. 

The problem is, the rogue-like elements are DIRECTLY AT ODDS with the RPG elements… But it's still not that big of a problem. Hear me out! Let's break it down!

[h2]#2 - Harsh-Browns Everyday and You Won't Know Why[/h2]

You're going to get REKT NERD because you face-checked a world tile and didn't realize that you landed in a swamp that has some freaking piranha eel that legit just eats your limbs. 

You're also going to continuously die in a place called Golgotha (Jesus died there and the fact that he rose again in spite of it has evolved/mutated my faith) and you'll question WHY DID I JUST DIE BRO?! *Involuntary Desk Slam!*

This game has had more “desk slamming” moments than freaking Tarkov bro. And I've played Tarkov for over 5 years! 

I die often and feel like I don't learn anything other than, “that thing can and will ruin my life”. In Dark Souls, the secret “level-up” is that you learn a little every time you die. You understand their movements a little better, you know what worked, and you're a better player almost every time you die. This is not always the case in Qud.

If you're going serve me harshbrowns every time I sit down at a location, teach me something man. I legit walked up to a freaking two headed Chuchu from Zelda and went from 60/150 to DEAD. What did I learn? I dunno but the logs were not conclusive. 

Maybe I should've just looked the creature up on the wiki… But that brings me to my next complaint. 

[h2]#3 - Communication is Healthy and Necessary in Every Marriage, Don't be a Silent Rogue [/h2]

Bro… Don't freaking give me a talking fungus on my back and then not give me solutions. Don't chop off my feet in a disagreement with a woodchipper bot and then ask me to hike back without a solution. 

There are ROGUE-LIKE things that happen to you in this game, but Qud doesn't talk to you about them.

In-game, Qud won't shut up about it's beautifully crafted world, deep character design, fascinating relationship systems, weird item systems, and wacked out races. And that's great for it. That's where you'll fall in love with Qud. 

Qud looking hella cute today eh? You know you wanna put a ring on it. 

So you spend countless evenings together, maybe stay up a little too late exploring… So you get married and commit to playing this game over the recent Tarkov wipe/tragedy or Marvel Rivals that you friends keep begging you to play. It's been weeks since you've seen your bros, and you're okay with that for now. It's the HONEYMOON PHASE with this game.

But then Qud won't freaking talk to you. Dang she's beautiful and she's so fun, but SHE WON'T TELL YOU WHY YOU HAVE A FUNGUS ON YOUR BACK OR HOW TO DEAL WITH IT! 

Little did you know… You were supposed to go to just the right location, talk to just the right person, and read the right book. I have nothing against reading, I actually really enjoyed that part. It was getting to the book that annoyed me. 

I had to go and look at the wiki in order to get to the conclusion. And GOD KNOWS I do enough of that in Tarkov. That crap is an abusive relationship bro. I married Qud because I didn't want to have to do that… I wanted a healthier relationship than that.

I should've been able to go to the doctor-esque person in the first town and strike up a natural conversation about the fungus or the missing limbs. And that's actually what I originally did, because the game is SO DEEP that I thought that would've happened. I would've been down if she gave me a hint to the book or something, I would've been totally fine with that. But being silent about an armless, fungus-covered doofus isn't something this game should do. 

Just communicate with me on these random rogue-like things. Because taking away an entire item slot can absolutely ruin my fun. And that's where a few rogue-like elements are still lingering to try and ruin what is one of the best RPGs I've ever played.

There's one *SPOILER* of a disease that literally ruined my progress in that fascinating story. Not once did one of the characters look at me and say, “Dang bro, I knew a guy that this happened to. I saw that same guy set a canteen on fire and drink it. It was NUTS!”

[h1]I Still Love You... Qud... [/h1] 

Alright I've ranted enough. This game is great. I love it. I think it's genius. 

We just need to continue growing together in this relationship and find our identities TOGETHER. I believe in you Qud. You're beautiful.

184002487.review:
Even though it is not categorized as such, I would sooner label Caves of Qud as a CRPG, with roguelike tendencies being secondary and occasionally ill-fitting. While on a micro-scale, on-the-spot generation of local zones circumvents a common CRPG drawback by making familiar locations just unfamiliar enough to remain exciting and fresh, on a macro-scale the spontaneity ingrained in the roguelike genre is scarcely found. Character-altering options that would be exciting in the context of a different game just aren't as appealing to a character that has been extensively planned and steadily built up for 30 hours. Similarly, permanent death is quite a divisive inclusion as while it instills the necessary tension for each situation to be taken seriously, it also just feels bad losing a character to a single lapse of judgment, or worse, to something completely unforeseen.

In a recent video titled 'Designing Caves of Qud', co-creator Jason Grinblat states that: "Caves of Qud is unique among RPG-type games in that it is driven by a complex physical, social and historical simulation, and this is what really sets it apart. Those simulation elements allow the RPG elements and tactical gameplay to flower on top of deep and colliding systems."

The reputation system's effect is a significant boon to the variety of engagement with virtually all of the regions and enemies in the game, but interacting with the system itself introduces a damaging degree of repetitiveness. The issue stems from new characters having a preset starting reputation with all factions, and more importantly from the distribution of creatures in the world and their levels within their factions. For instance, all [spoiler]snapjaw[/spoiler] variants are low-level creatures that rapidly become a non-threat, whereas [spoiler]oozes[/spoiler] are present in nearly every terrain type and have members whose levels range from low to endgame. This means that reputation importance is homogenized across all but challenge or roleplay runs, but this ties into my next point.

Each run having a unique, randomly generated history is a novel concept, but it ends up being disappointing as it's made clear that nearly all of the lore offers no strategic value. Don't get me wrong; the many lore entries and reputation snippets on legendary creatures are amusing to read, and flavor is certainly valuable, but ultimately they're as amusing as random generation allows. The more you get exposed to the dataset and the patterns, the more the flavor diminishes until it is completely tuned out. The term 'random generation' is meant literally here—Sultan lore will at best reveal which creature types to expect in their respective historic sites or hint at the qualities of their relic, but there is no point in a holistic approach as there is no history to piece together. I can recall investing a lot of effort into engaging with the history system on my first decent run of the game. Reading each entry was exciting as I was under the impression that it mattered. This is in stark contrast to how I engage with this system hundreds of hours later, where I only gather historic entries because it's convenient to do so while autoexploring. The negative effect of random generation also extends to the legendary creatures—randomly generating faction relationship descriptors means that factions won't be consistently characterized, which severely limits roleplaying. Controlling the randomness would've gone a long way in polishing these systems. For example, filtering the descriptors into themed pools and then randomly assigning one to each faction during world generation would've retained the variety achieved through randomness while giving factions an identity. The sky was the limit here, and I'm highly critical of these systems as they should've been a huge win in the game's favor, but as it stands, runs are indistinguishable by their "complex social and historical simulation."

One last thing I'd like to address is the inconsistencies in certain balance changes. In the abovementioned video, Jason Grinblat also states that "Qud is a game that's okay with the player breaking it over the knee". While this statement rings true, the game seems quite selective about how it allows the player to break it. Methods of breaking the game's economy such as [spoiler]lava freezing[/spoiler] and most recently [spoiler]warm static pouring[/spoiler] have been nerfed to the point of redundancy, yet other, similarly effective methods which are even simpler to perform remain inexplicably unchanged. This unevenness is jarring and it is compounded by the invalidation of niche mechanics that perfectly fit in with the bizarre aesthetic as removing tools from the sandbox runs counter to the game's many ideals.

This was not meant to be a balanced review but a critical examination of a video game that is singular, evocative, and whose unique qualities have compelled me to put my thoughts into writing. Even though the majority have been negative, the one thing I would want anyone who reads this to take with them is that in spite of some misguided choices and missed opportunities Caves of Qud is wholly worth experiencing.
