True Kin Tale of Caves of Qud

As an aristocrat and one of the True Kin, I’ve witnessed the rise and fall of many ventures - grand and small - but nothing quite compares to the awe-inspiring marvel that is Caves of Quid. This game doesn’t merely deliver; it ensnares the senses, captivating both mind and body. From my elevated vantage, I can appreciate the rich intricacies woven into its mechanics, which offer a depth rarely seen in modern experiences. Each decision carries weight, and every move feels deliberate, as though the world itself bends to your will - an intoxicating feeling for one such as myself.

What truly elevates this game, however, is the staggering diversity of factions present within the game. As an individual of notable status, I’ve always admired the nuance and complexity of power dynamics, and here, the factions are not mere entities but living, breathing parts of the world. Their motivations, goals, and actions ripple through the game’s layers in ways that make each encounter feel unique. You will never meet the same challenge twice, whether you’re negotiating with cunning political players, battling ruthless warlords, or exploring the subterranean labyrinths of forgotten realms.

Speaking of exploration, the world is an immense tapestry, stretching endlessly in every direction. My True Kin ancestors often spoke of expansive territories, but even their stories pale in comparison to the sheer scale of Caves of Quid. The game’s size is awe-inspiring, with hidden corners and secrets waiting to be uncovered. What sets it apart is the freedom it grants you in how to approach each challenge—whether you choose diplomacy, brute force, or more subtle forms of manipulation, the paths are as diverse as the factions themselves.

No matter how you choose to navigate the world, Caves of Quid adapts, allowing each player to carve their own legacy within its walls. This is not merely a game, but an experience of staggering complexity—one that promises to challenge even the most seasoned of strategists. For someone like me, accustomed to control and calculation, the experience is nothing short of exhilarating. In every way, Caves of Quid embodies a triumph of design, a world where every decision and every moment feels like a step toward an unknown but enticing future.

If there is one downside to Caves of Quid, it lies in its steep learning curve. The game's distinctive graphics style - minimalistic yet deeply intricate - can be overwhelming at first, particularly for those unaccustomed to its abstract approach. Coupled with the sheer amount of systems and mechanics to master, the early hours can feel like a barrage of new information. However, I would not call this a true flaw, but rather a challenge that enriches the experience. Like a complex political maneuver or the subtle art of negotiation, mastering the game's nuances becomes an achievement in itself. The difficulty of learning isn’t a barrier but an invitation to truly immerse oneself, and for those willing to rise to it, Caves of Quid offers an unparalleled depth of satisfaction.

183896591.review:
Amazing classic roguelike, made with so much love and attention to detail. Unlike most classic roguelikes this one actually has a wonderfully coherent world, an immersive and engaging plot, and the best in 2-color spritework you'll see in a long time.

My initial experience with this was flailing about in permadeath mode and dying a lot, then disabling permadeath to experience the full depth and story of the game at least once, and I would recommend everyone do the same. Flailing about is fun, because you're brought into an unfamiliar world full of original game mechanics you don't see anywhere else, but the main plot is long and dangerous enough that it would be a shame if you just died in the middle and had to restart from scratch a bunch of times because you were unfamiliar with all the high-level enemies and advanced equipment. Once you've seen everything, you can reenable permadeath to add the classic roguelike thrill while you try out the immense variety of character builds.

EDIT: The ending made me cry. Double recommend.

Unfortunately, this isn’t a game you try and immediately say WOW right from the start. You need to give it 2–3 hours with different characters to really appreciate it. But once you do, it becomes very rewarding. The graphics are...well...special...pixels and old-school text everywhere. Everything is turn-based. However, I have to admit that with the keyboard shortcuts for all actions and the UI, the developers made the gameplay (exploration, interaction, combat) surprisingly smooth and enjoyable. You just have to get used to it.

The history of the world is procedurally generated, and you’re dropped into the middle of it, somewhere in a random village at a random time. When you talk to characters, you quickly realize that they talk a lot of nonsense. But the journal is your friend and really helps you separate the blabla from the important stuff.

After starting over multiple times, even without paying too much attention, you begin to grasp the meaning behind the dialogue, the items, and the world, it just starts to flow. The game has a main questline, but thanks to procedural world generation, every new run feels completely different. You’ll encounter a lot of lore, strange characters, and unique places throughout the game, making it a great experience with a lot of replayability.

183637265.review:
I rarely leave negative reviews and generally prefer to give a thumbs up while explaining my dislikes. But in this instance I will do the opposite and give a thumbs down and try to find the positives.

Most positive reviews mention how "deep" this game and that is entirely true. They also mention the simplistic graphics and complicated interface which, somehow, add to the game ... which I explain as a kind of exagerated/added complexity that is not necessary, but becomes part of the charm of playing the game, learning at every step. I guess I'm nostalgic for that kind of experience, like when I played ruthless games on NES and SNES as a kid. "Tutorial" is a word I've heard for the first time decades after I started playing games, so I usually enjoy the painful process of learning to master a complex and ruthless game that requires you to start over and over again, until you "git gud" enough to  beat it.

But the Caves of Qud have beat me. Many of you will say that 5 hours is not enough for me to have learned enough about the game to "get good 'nuf" to learn to beat and I would agree with them, since for the first 2 hours I really enjoyed dying every 5 minutes. Then I enjoyed the next 3 hours when I actually took the time to read a guide, learn how to pay close attention to everything going on around my character, actually "look" at everything and I've learned ways to fight creatures I should have died to until I got to higher levels ... and then just hit another glass ceiling that I could have overcome ... but I kind of was tired and made the mistake of not noticing the differences in the enemy I was fighting.

And this is where Caves of Qud breaks me. I played a lot of roguelike games that made me run through lots of hoops, dying and restarting a lot along the way until I either figured it out or got a lucky run, then died some more until I figured it out. Where Caves of Qud earns a negative reviews is that I was expecting different runs, in some ways, but the caves just make me go through the same hoops, on the same map, with the same quests ... every ... time.

I do not believe this game earns it's procedural generation because I really do not feel in any way that any of my runs were really that much different. Yea, I might get killed by the score of different enemy types I have encountered and it's a crap shoot wether or not the generation decided to put an impossible challenge in front me right at the start, which forces me to maybe find a different way of levelling up (and hopefully that one I can tackle) but that's not even what really bothers me with the game.

Nope, what bothers me is: every. run. feels. the. exact. same. Even when I encounter different monsters in different ruins ! Maybe it's the graphics, maybe it's fact that I do not have the patience to read some entirely home brewed lore with made up words that have no real given meaning and are just brushed on the surface without being expanded.

I really am not sure what my gripe with this game is besides saying that playing it feels like I'm trapped in groundhog's day, even though I have already tried every character (or are they classes ? I dunno) twice at least, trying to learn their differences ... without feeling much of a difference at all between different characters/classes. Even the choice of the starting world is a joke. It's a different village, always located in the same region of the map on a static map.

I feel like I was fooled into thinking this game had some replayability. I don't feel like it has much of that. Maybe I'll come back to it some day and "get the hype", but right now I can't say that I do.

183628270.review:
[h1]Chewin' Muh Qud[/h1]

[b]Caves of Qud = Nethack + Dune + Xavier: Renegade Angel[/b]

I won't dip into the various wacky stories I've experiences in my first blissful 100 hours of Qud, as many others have already shared similar stories. Instead, what I really want to share is that this is the heir apparent, more than any game I've played in a couple decades, of Nethack. You will hear people liken this game to Dwarf Fortress, but that isn't terribly accurate beyond aesthetics. It is far closer to Nethack and the OG Rogue. Although there has been an endless sea of true rogue-likes since the days of Rogue and Nethack - many of them VERY good - Caves of Qud is the first game I've played that brought back the true Nethack feels.

I don't need to explain what that means to those that spent many an hour trying to swipe the Amulet of Yendor, but for everyone else: Caves of Qud is, boiled down, a game that hates you in a way that will make you love it. I am very happy to see that there are non-permadeath modes, as this game has an atmosphere absolutely worth exploring to the fullest, but Classic is where it's at. This game will lull you into a false sense of security only to brutally - and literally - explode your head in the next 60 seconds.

There is a lot of noise about the random and bizarre aspects of this game, but not enough is said about the sheer tactical joy you will experience. Allow me to illustrate:

I came across some ruins that I'd yet to explore. Ruins can potentially yield several highly valuable resources, so I opt to explore. I am an Esper, something I would liken to a Psyker from Warhammer 40k and the Highlander. I sense that another Esper from the dimension of Bubblebutt or whatever is nearby. Anyone who has played will tell you that two Espers meeting is an extremely tense moment, and that, much like Highlander, There Can Be Only One. I carefully pick my way into the ruins and suddenly find myself encased in a forcefield and can't move. Too bad I don't have a Reality Grenade to counter the psychic phenomenon. Immediately after that, the enemy tries to burrow into my mind in order to literally cause my head to explode. Fortunately, my Mental Mirror reflects the attack. What it doesn't reflect is the Cryokinesis the Psychic Interdimensional Horse - yes, like Mr. Ed - Assassin drops on me, freezing me solid inside the forcefield. I excite the molecules of air around the horse, creating a wildfire. Now we are both inconvenienced. I thaw out, but have taken some damage. The forcefield breaks, I begin gathering the innate light I generate to burn holes into the Horse with pinpoint accurate lasers. I fire off a couple such psychic lasers, but the Horse begins to try and invade my mind again. Unfortunately, my Mental Mirror hasn't regenerated, and I am taking significant damage each round. Worse, if I don't break the link, I will suffer head-explodingly catestrophic damage after a few rounds. Thinkthinkthink! AH! I use my teleport to move myself inside of the ruins! This causes the Horse to lose track of me and it isn't able to tunnel into my mind any longer. Oh, but the Horse has a trick up its sleeve! A vortex of swirling unreality summoned almost on top of me that can literally suck me in and teleport me to Rasheph knows where. No problem! I will just activate Sprint and dash - Oops. Problem! I teleported into a huge pool of salt water and am waist-deep in brine, I can't sprint! I struggle to stay clear of the Vortex and the worst thing happens - or does it? Althought the Horse has no line of sight to me, it obviously senses my general location and generates another patch of enervating cold... This time, however, it fails to encase me in ice. Ah, but it DOES freeze the water underneath me, giving me solid ground to stand on! I use my Jump ability to clear the last block of water and barely manage to evade the all-consuming vortex! I've had enough of this equine at this point, and bring my dual chain-pistols to bear... I come around a wall and begin sprinting directly toward the damn old nag, spraying bullets from my pistols literally all over the place. The Horse tries to zap me with lasers of its own, but my own high skill in the same psychic talent causes the beam to bounce harmlessly away. Just to be on the safe side, I erect a forcefield of my own, and pump a wild stream of bullets in the Horse's general direction until it is dead. Upon it's death, I have the choice to absorb it's psyche and permanently increate my power. In doing so, I become even more of an attractive beacon to the ever-hungry mind-devourers from the infinite dimensions.

I hit "y" on my keyboard.

Let them come.

[i]Seek the Kasaphesence if you...[/i]

[list]
[*] 💧 Liked Rogue/Nethack. Caves of Qud is the true evolution - or mutation - of the genre.
[*] 💧 Enjoy unforgivingly punishing and tactical gameplay.
[*] 💧 Are a big fan of barbaro-futuristic sci-fi (ie - Sci-fi that feels like fantasy).
[/list]

[i]Abandon Your Character if you...[/i]

[list]
[*] 🧂 Don't like sudden difficulty spikes (the main story quests can be BRUTAL)
[*] 🧂 Don't want to F with a complicated game
[*] 🧂 Are looking for "sim" elements as found in games like Dwarf Fortess

[u]The Bottom Line[/u]

Caves of Qud has something to offer for many. The graphics are surprisingly immersive despite being tile-based (seeing the enemy's ashes scatter to the wind as you vaporize them with lasers never gets old). The lore is rich, if a bit samey. There are some extremely intriguing characters to meet and the game is very inclusive. It is always a joy to roll a new character. Though there is a lot of repetition in runs, there will be moments of novelty almost every time that catch you off guard. The main "loop" I would say, consists of doing a lot of dungeon delving and trading to stock yourself up H E A V I L Y for the next leg of the main story. Locking yourself into one mode of problem-solving is death. Having tons of redundant plans is life. To that end, there is a lot of "boring" grinding (personally, I would call it relaxing) to level up and stock up on gear that will see you through the next brutally punishing main dungeon.  You can't relax completely, however, and if you get lacksadasical the game will - literally - swallow you whole and devour your character.

[h1]Salutation: Live And Drink.[/h1]

183592603.review:
I bought this game mainly to play on the Steam Deck.

I'll start with the negatives and mention that I refunded this game once but decided to buy it again.

First of all, the tutorial bugs out on PC. If you're playing with a mouse and keyboard, be prepared for the game to glitch—at least at the time of this review, on version 1.0.

Strangely enough, the process works perfectly on the Steam Deck.

Negative points for me:

I'm not a big fan of this type of setting, where the future feels more like fantasy. I would prefer a more serious tone, but I’ve managed to tolerate it.

I believe the graphics are part of the game's charm, but the UI is confusing. I think this is a recurring issue with roguelikes: they often have a lot of depth, but the user interface is always a tiresome learning curve.

I'm still figuring out some keys and buttons to get by. So far, it's working, but I haven’t yet experienced the freedom that many people mention. However, I have less than 3 hours of playtime, so that might change.

The music is terrible. Unfortunately, I found it repetitive and poorly composed, ruining the game’s atmosphere and overall feeling. I turned it off, and it was much better. Some areas lack ambient sounds, but when they’re present, the game succeeds in conveying a mysterious vibe and the atmosphere of an intriguing book.

Now for the positive aspects that made me repurchase the game, even after struggling with the PC interface and tutorial bugs:

The game works on the Steam Deck.

It’s almost surprising that a game with such a confusing UI can work with so few buttons, but it does. It takes some time to get used to, but it’s very interesting, and the game manages to hook you in.

It’s engaging precisely because it’s so vast. Each area is a surprise, and the difficulty isn’t as absurd as RPGs from the '80s or '90s. It gives you room to grow, level up, and even abuse powerful skills to deal with enemies.

Not to mention the roleplay aspect—the game has checkpoints, which breaks the roguelike mold and lets you retry. For instance, I kept dying to a red bear, but by using a skill like "STAREDOWN," you can intimidate enemies into fleeing, giving you time to recover and land a few more hits.

While I’d prefer a less fantastical setting, the game works well regardless. Its unique graphical style and the curiosity it sparks make you want to keep playing.

I’m still new to roguelikes of this type. I’ve wanted to play CDDA, for example, but every version I’ve tried is buggy or has a painful UI. I believe Caves of Qud is a unique experience that’s worth it.

The price felt a bit steep, but most roguelikes of this type are similarly priced.

I recommend the game. I don’t consider it perfect, but it’s different enough to spark curiosity and is great to play while lying down.

And remember: it runs great on the Steam Deck!

Thank you.

183573012.review:
A very interesting setting. It seems like Dune and Conan at first, but you slowly come to realize you're exploring the post-post-apocalypse of a high-tech setting. Every game starts with a procedurally generated history of Qud's sultanates, which you will discover as you delve into ruins and historical sites, trying to sort out fact from superstition.

There's also a faction system that is tied into the procedural history and interacted with the sultans. Every important character (including random legendaries) will have allies and enemies, who will be pleased or angered when you kill them or ceremoniously share your water with them. Doing the latter is the only way to trade secrets or learn free skills.

There's lots of build variety: I've been a regenerating berserker axe turtle, a multilegged technopath kiting everything while setting up turrets, and a pyrokinetic psychic making enemies' head explode with my brain (until my ego literally got so big that psychic assassins started showing up to devour my mind). You can also reject the way of the mutant and be a pure human, who get various perks including exclusive access to cybernetics, which can match or surpass mutant powers but must be found in ruins or traded for.

It has three difficulty options (permadeath, checkpoints when you leave settlements, or free exploration), and a useful official wiki.

183554263.review:
Qud is weird. It's incredibly interesting, hugely random (yet strangely repetitive, as random generation often ends up being) and, for all its far future mutant and science fiction oddness, rather more traditional than it pretends to be. As in, it's powered by dice rolls and many classic dnd/roguelike mechanics and has graphics that hark back to 30 years ago. 

The writing is beyond purple into the ultraviolet. As a stylistic choice, I initially liked it, but it quickly became so much background-cruft. Yes, yes, I'm sure it's exciting that that this item "gleams with nanothings sundered from the spacetime braid" or somesuch, but should I equip it? Oh, no clue? In a game where a non zero amount of things will kill you more or less instantly without warning? Off to the wiki I go for the information that wasn't accessible to me in the game, then. Even though I have an implant that specifically exists to identify artifacts for me....

The multiple ending story is far too long for traditional roguelike play, in my inexpert opinion, as you'll probably maintain a run for double-digit hours to get near the end. It's a shame that you can't reload earlier saves to experience the multiple endings, since there's no way I'm making another character to do so. I thought the collision of inclusive sensibilities and old testament references in a weird post future world was cool, not that the story does especially much with any of those things.

One thing worth mentioning is that this game wants you to break it, or even cheese it. There are dozens of ways of breaking the economy, and five or six different ways of basically becoming borderline immortal (not that the game won't randomly spawn enemies that will straight up kill even extremely strong characters without any warning -you have to look at everything you haven't seen before and consider "should I hit the bricks rather than find out why that thing has an "impossible" rating?" If you're not ending the game with a small army of clones of yourself or wielding enough weapons that you resemble a battleship, you're doing something wrong.

Now that I've completed the story, I feel like I've seen 90% of what it has to offer. For a world with almost infinite places beneath the earth, I don't feel the need to see any more of them, particularly. It was a lot of fun, and I'd recommend giving it a go if you think you might enjoy a combat-heavy, deliberately strange turn-based game.
